review_title: Very bad. Not worth the download.
one_reviews_text: No disrespect to the war veterans. I am sure it was a horrible experience. But this VR "experience" is very bad. Not worth the download or the space it takes up on your PC or Quest. Graphics are bad, the interior of the plane is too dark and the exterior (which you can see as you clip through the plane) is a joke. Looks like its made by somebody with very poor design skills. As a game developer myself, I am horrified. I don't know how BBC could let anyone put their name on this. The rating is only high because of the emotions the original audio transmits. All respect to the war veterans, but this is an insult to those people. Don't waste your time experiencing this.

review_title: Hauntingly affecting and very right too
one_reviews_text:
What a truly wonderful thing to have done.  I have known of the original recording for many years, it calls out through history as an act of bravery recorded.   Only now though do you have the true sense of the cramped conditions and helplessness of the crew on the persitent mission where calm is all you can offer yourself when luck will have it's way with you.

It would have been nice to see some other positions within the bomber like tail and mid-gunner positions but however that's as much a statement of the success of this experience, I just want to see more and more of it.

A wonderful work to do honour to all of the men involved.  Well done and indeed thank you.
absolute master piece .... after watching this i had to sit down it brought me to tears .... thank u for giving me this ... thank u
Great experiance. Really wish they would port it to the Quest 2. It would be a great experiance to show people and introduce them to VR
Proof if it were needed of the potential power of VR and the irreplaceable value of the BBC.
- want more !
an amazing insight into what they went through

This is how we can use VR to learn history. It's a great experience that you can feel on your own. To remember what people of that time feel during the war. When they were risking their lifes for better future. More products like this.

An acurate depiction of history without the modern "woke" take or manipulation which is rare with Oculus (because its facebook owned) and even more rare because this particular piece was created by the BBC (the leftist and European funded ""broadcasting"" company), all that aside this is great work, its a very short experience but well worth remaining in your inventry, this is also important for the younger audience to witness, that many hardships and losses from all sides of what was the most real war to have ever existed, told by the voices of those that were living it, its only a very small portion of the events of the time but enough to make some people realise that today they are lucky that they are not strapped into a flying fortress, bolted together and bruised whilst underfire over hostile foreign lands with a very small chance of returning home. The apps experience is comfortable for new vr users and doesnt expect anything from a user when it coems to input. Ran perfectly on  a ROG Strix with nvidia GTX1070

This was one of the best VR experiences I've had, and its just simple and nothing special gamplay wise. I hope they make more like this, i will buy every experience they do like this. I even want to make some stuff like this now.

the only gripe, is the credits for the military airmen showed on screen for too short. the other people who just made the game had credits that lingered on screen much longer :( . literally finally the one time i want to read the peoples names in the credits and it goes away too fast

also would love subtitles, because i often had trouble hearing exactly what they were saying
Everyone should see this, not just because its cool, but to also actually learn something about history.

review_title: Excellent use of VR and original audio
one_reviews_text: This is by far the most moving experience I have seen in VR. The combination of VR visuals and original audio from the actual raid makes for a compelling experience. It is impossible not to marvel at the bravery of those young men when you hear their actual voices and see something of what they saw. While also remembering the civilian deaths, the bravery of those airmen should be an inspiration to future generations.

This is the perfect use of VR. Showed it to my dad, who is obsessed with all things airplane and WWII, as his first VR experience and he was blown away. The real audio and solid graphics make this really immersive. It's free. Download this if you don't already have it.

review_title: One of the best VR Experiences
one_reviews_text: History brought to life.

...of creating the visual footage for existing audio recordings. Feels like time-travel, and immersive in that way. Would love to see this with more commentary/critique. Right now, feels like a pro-military honorific, rather than examined history/analysis

My great uncle was a navigator on a lank.  Unfortunatly was kia over Germany.  Was an emotional journey I went through.  I was able to look exactly where he would have been sitting.   Its the closet I ever get to going through what he went through every 48 hours.   Thanks BBC.  you connected me to my great uncle far more than i could have ever thought possible.

Bombing 200.000 civilians to death, how fun. Take that violin and break it over your own head. More and more people are learning about ww2 and things are not as the system wants it to seem it to be. Germany got robbed long before ww1, then in ww1 they got robbed for the landmasses and postwar lied about everything.

The history is disgusting, tho I can feel for the soldiers and aviators.
Simply brilliant-immensly moving and powerful  A credit to the BBC .
Enjoyable short experiance for anyone who loves WW2 history.

This experience is like a movie with you seated in the plane beside the other airmen. It was an insightful look into the journey of the WWII allied bombers. The recreation of the flight and the search lights was enough to make me breathe faster. I almost fell out of my chair trying to look out the window of the plane! An up close and personal look at history. I got choked up at the end. Those men deserve to be remembered. I can't wait to show this to my dad who loves European history.

Very well implimented, the use of the actual radio broadcast was excellent. This just goes to show you what these men and women went through during the second world war. Very informative on the mission status. Hope to see more released from the devs.

Just that little feeling, and the historic voices, made me realize what it must have been like to do the bombing raids over and over again. How these chaps dealt with it and their will to get the job done comes across as a stark contrast to the attitudes of today.

Instead of learning just a bit of what happen in world war 2 through boring classes and some documentries. This VR gives you a glispe first hand of what these pilots had been through and it's just rough seeing that citizens are risking their lives for the sake of freedom. The detailing was great,  but hope BBC and other history medias continue to make content like this with better graphics, detailing, interactivity, etc.

review_title: Amazing and a bit heart wrenching
one_reviews_text: Wow, I’ve always been interested in history, especially the period of the world wars and this experience really puts you into the seat of a allied bomber and shows just what these men endured for us

to think they used to say a picture is worth a thousand words, most of my vr experiencs till now have been science fiction but to combine a real factual account with an imersive experience..  well done bbc, well done
Thanks to all the Pilots back then, that helped to free Germany from Faschsim. Thanks BBC for that state-of-the-art pice helping not to forget.
Being new to VR I am still not quite knowing what to expect. This blew me away. I know Berlin well, but to be in that plane..Wow. God bless the memory of all those brave lads. Makes you humble

Like many others I found this to be  a moving experience. You can remain seated but I liked to stand from time to time to get get a better view (although being seated makes you appreciate the cramped conditions and very limited visibility of most of the crew).  Well done BBC.
you really feel for all the crew members and you are watching out of the window waiting for something bad to happen

this is something i shall make sure i keep. 
talk about ground you and put a few things in perspective. 
using technology and achieving something. keeping something alive literally. 

would be nice to see more of history like this. 

my only gripe, and its a minor one.. 
camera placement. i felt like i was in the way.
Never knew anything about the year 1943. Until now! It totally is worth to give the game a check.

I love flying and aviation, and I love WWII allied bombers. So just the menu experience of sitting next to a Lancaster and feel it's huge size in VR while parked on a war field on a late afternoon was impressive. 
Then, the actual experience begins with that long, heavy takeoff, it got me there. The thundering rumble of those 4 engines, the flames coming out of their exhaust, all felt real. 
Then how dynamic and expressive the crew models are as you hear their voices speak and - yup - sing. I just felt the experience was too short, I might even have endured the whole 8 hour long flight although I might be in minority here. But longer scenes would be most welcome.
Above all, it's an eye opening experience for the sacrifices of so many young men not that long ago, and the respect they deserve for their courage. You can feel their vulnerability in this experience. And they would do this time and time again. The majority didn't return home. I hope their sacrifice is not forgotten. 
This is a wonderful way to help us remember them.
Fascinating experience .Thinking of , close to my place one of these terror bombers came down with only two survivors.
Exceptional!!

review_title: I am of German Origin, served the Army..
one_reviews_text:
...for many Years, im a Enthusiast in History in global and special of WW 2 - but this Masterpiece here, this little Piece of Audio Documentary, visualized, made even me crying and feeling ashamed about what we, talking of all human beeings, made out of the world today, after those brave men sacrificed theirs for a better future. 

This documentary should be re-visited by any schoolar, any human beeing in europe, so that this what happened then would never happen again!

thank you, developers of that documentary for your contribution to VR and History World. Thank you all, who suffered and sacrificed their lives for us, for a better future - and forgive us, that we messed up like we did!

Reliving history as a part of events as they unfold is vastly more impactful that words on a page.  I'd love to see more of this sort of thing developed, especially more WWII content, but any historical event would be much appreciated.

One note for passerbys:  Make sure not to move too much between scenes; it seems eye level is reset with each transition, so a few were a bit strangely set as I was looking around, soaking everything in.

Good graphics and authentic commentray made this the closest I have ever come to experiencing what it must have been like being aboard an Lancaster bomber on a night time bombing mission. My great uncle once did exactly what that commentator did. He was a deskbound administrator at an RAF aerodrome and begged a crew to take him on a mission one night.  So they did, and afterwards he vowed never to do it again! The Lancaster he was on returned with a gaping hole in the side of the fuselage. I often wondered what it must have been like for him and this has given me the perfect insight.

review_title: So impactful I got heavy breathing
one_reviews_text: I play every game and watch every movie and I cry sometimes but for the first time I started to hyperventilate.  I don't know if it was the authentic commentator or the surprise at the tightness of all those souls slammed into that tiny area but I was the farthest I've been towards lost it from media.  Sure I've yelled and cried at some military movies but nothing like VR.

Really enjoyed this app.  Am a retired military officer and a World War II buff, so this was right up my alley.  Good graphics, good sense of realism, and I enjoyed how you could stay in the aircraft or stand up (literally) and see outside of the aircraft.  (Riding the wing as we crossed the English coast on way home was exceptionally cool).   Great educational experience; sobering and emotional and very real.

Being a history major and teacher, I've always held a fascination for documentaries.  This puts you in the plane on a bombing run.  The animations are great and the characters seem very lifelike.  How they remain so calm boggles my mind! I wish it were a bit longer.  I hope in the future they can make more like this.  A+

To create this from an actual recording is a very clever way of preserving history and presenting it in a palatable format for younger generations. I applaud the devs for making this, it's both beautiful and horrific, the visuals and the reality. 
I've seen many a war film and all are upsetting, as they should be, I think this just enhanced my thoughts on how much effort went in to wasting so many precious lives and the everyday horrors that could befall people on both sides. 
Meanwhile the commentary from the host and crew is so very British in the face of such terror.
I would very much wish for more educational and entertaining experiences of this caliber. Highly recommended.

This is an EXCELLENT experience.  At Squadron Officer School we have used this to support lessons on air power and history. 
Are you going to port this to the quest?

Especially the broadcast lacks self-reflection of the commentator. Even with the significant time between the war and revisiting his memories it appears that his views are frozen in time. At times the commentary reminded me of an animal documentary.
You will defentley remember this experience for a loong time ;)

Yeah, I'm surprised as well. Good on ya'.

So, this is basically something that could easily have been made into a short film at a museum (though I think someone out there running a museum for old planes has stumbled across this and had the idea), but without you having to pay entrance fees to experience.

It seems almost faked with how nonchalantly the entire crew is about the situation. Usually when you hear of bombing runs over high profile targets, everyone's super tensed up with their planes being hit by Flakk from all over. Here it's just that posh british accent going "gee, is that a Jerry fighter? Oh gosh, it is. Gunner, take care of it, would you? I'll prepare the tea". But it's actual recordings of the flight crew interactions...

Would definitely recommend if you're interested in learning about what a bombing crew had to deal with during bombing runs. Would definitely not recommend if you don't like watching documentaries.

review_title: I'm not gonna lie: I cried.
one_reviews_text:
While watching this fantastic experience, I couldn't contain my tears. It's really different just reading about it or seeing a movie about it and actually watching this in VR and uncommented original sound.

I can't even say what made me cry the most. The calmness of the bomber crew in the face of death on the grace of a coin flip, being a born Berliner and seeing your city burn to ashes, thinking about the state of the world back then and today, knowing this really happened or the sheer loss of life that happened, leaving back no winners, just less losers.

Events like this can't ever happen again in Europe and should cease to happen all over the world. I hate to admit, that the ideology on which something like this grew in Germany and all over the world, did not vanish from this planet. Even some few of the comments on this master piece carry equally nationalistic views.

We need to learn from these horrors.

I didn't expect to feel anything from this but I was so wrong.  Riding along with the stalwart crew as flak explodes around you.  It is just a glimps of what it must have been like to know your life is just a roll of the dice away from ending.  I don't know why I got so emotional but I was hit hard.  This is absolutely worth your time!
I've always wondered what Band of Brothers or the Pacific would feel like in real life. This is it. Great job BBC.

This was produced by the BBC and it has all the quality you would expect. Yes it only lasts about 15 minutes, but it is fascinating from start to finish. If you stand up during the show you get to go outside the plane and see the evolving story even better.

Not going to overhype it, it's low resolution, really short, not alot of details but this is one of those cases where one of that mattered.

After years of public school I've written countless reports about WWII. I've gone to musiums, wrote papers, heck I even have a copy of Band of Brothers on my bookshelf.
This story was good knowing that these were recordings so it isn't like you could or would want to change what really happened. It's a shame that there was 0 interaction with it but the simple scenes let you focus on the recordings.
You're in a small cabin, engines on both sides going none stop, and just taking a moment to reflect yourself on to these men, thinking that that could be your final resting place while the ground below you is on fire is unsettling.

For what it was worth I think it makes for a nice education tool and a great way to feel the perspective of who had to lived through this.

I hope the developers are proud of what they have accomplished. In a way I could relate to the navigator, in the back trying to focus while a thin sheet of metal seperates you from hell on Earth. It's the little things that give us the most comfort.

As a day-1 VR vet, this is one of the best things I've tried in VR. There is just something incredible about experiencing what this crew went through with the reporter's real commentary.

This can be deeply emotional and I think everyone should try this.
I highly recomend this experience to any and all. It's not violent or scary

review_title: How does this have a comfortable rating?
one_reviews_text:
I've never felt bad or got motion sickness from any VR game, even with "Intense" ratings. I guess now I can't say the same thing for regular emotional sickness.
Taking off, I felt that this was going to be just a chill, fly over and yell "bombs' away!" and that'd be it. Flying over Berlin, watching the plane just in front of mine go down and watching the flak explode only meters away at times, I actually cried. I started to get the biggest feeling of dread, and I wanted to get out. I could never imagine doing that in real life. An amazing experience.
Highly recomend if you even have a remote interest in WW2 history. Super well done, and the real audio of the banter of the crew members just makes it so perfectly authentic.

I was skeptical, regardless of the price.  I saw it was a free download, read the reviews, and decided to see for myself.  I was not disappointed.  This is a MUST see for everyone.  I could not believe the attention to detail, the immersion, the feelings of dread as I sat there and watched what these brave men had to face.  The overwhelming sense of fear, then disbelief, and finally...well, I'll let you decide...if I could give this more than 5 stars I would.  This kind of experience showcases exactly what VR can do in terms of immersion and education.  10/10.
So I guess it's ok to enjoy about bomb crew surviving a run as long as the casualties are German civilians. Disgusting.

I was breathless when experiencing the crew arrival to Germany, place really looked like hell on earth; incredible recreation of materials and sounds, as well as characters; Audio is remastered from original dialogue (which is awesome) however for non native speakers might be dificult to get every detail...it also leaves a sense of guilt from both sides of the story
...but i have to stay some moments for myself now. this was so intense, i didnt expect it.

review_title: When the World still had HEROS
one_reviews_text:
Only had VR for a few days now but this just shows how good VR can be. 
This is a must watch. 
Thank you for celebrating those that gave everything for us.
it really feels like being there

The part where one Lancaster drops its incendiaries off target, over some random part of Berlin... The businesslike attitude of the crew, depite knowing that half of them would probably not make it back home... The people below, getting bombed back to the stone age while a reporter above gives a cheerful running commentary... This is a fantastic way to present an extraordinary story.
The graphics are excellent,the audio is haunting and the levity of the mission is granular,chilled me to the bone......

this app was an amazing experience especially if your intrested in war and history.  It gives you the feeling of what its like to be there and it makes it very educational with the real recording of the report. The only reason I would give it 4 stars is its lack of replayability but it makes up for this being a free game. Overall fantastic 10/10 would get.

review_title: Great new way to make a documentary
one_reviews_text: Great new way to make a documentary
Brilliant
Great way to experience the horrors of ww2

this was beyond awesome .a very good way to get the "feeling"of what is was like to have been there.i can see future of education with these kinda movies.maybe more of different nations ?since i was standing in my room i didnt get scared but i can imagine beeingn there would have been stressfull. great experience keep it up
I love it. No problems. Immerisve. Educational. I learned a lot. Scenes felt very long.
What a fantastic experience.  As this tech gets better so will these types of experiences.

This recreation was truly exceptional. Very few VR experiences make me emotional. This gave me a glimmer of what I'd only heard about. It's a free application, so I can only give my thanks to BBC and the developers. (Don't worry about the BBC; they get plenty of my money in other ways :-)

review_title: One of the best VR experiences
one_reviews_text: Wonderful experience. Any plans to convert it for Quest?
I love VR gaming, but it is experiences like this that really show the true power of VR to none gamers. Bravo to the BBC and everyone else involved in the making of this fantastic experience.
I don't have anything to add that other reviewers haven't already said below. A truly amazing historical VR experience and unexpectedly emotional. Download it now.

I like how immesrive it is to when it was recorded and all of the details that were included, but I dont see why anti-aircraft shots coming towards you as you hear a recording of people going out to risk thier life and every shot you saw represented was an actual shot that couldve killed the people you are hearing and seeing being represented. My only dislike with this that is actually in the thing is that with all of the Immersion when an animation loop happens it really meeses with my head. I enjoyed the expereice overall. 5/5
One of the best made short VR experiences that I have seen.
I enjoyed this experience all the way! Emotional and graphically beautiful!
Words can't describe just download it
Amazing what they did with this.
top class vr experiance.  a masterpiece from the developers. well done
A great recording of the true heart the british show when our backs are against the wall.

This was really cool, but only if you're into history. Otherwise, it might bore you. I was constantly walking through the plane walls to see what was going on below me because the angles inside the plane didn't allow you to see much.

review_title: Very cool step back in time
one_reviews_text:
I guess I'm still the starry-eyed kid on the Oculus Rift block.  I am perplexed by the less-than-stellar reviews here.  Being a history buff and being familiar with this particular slice of time, I got the chills, literally, as I flew along with the bomber crew and was looking into their faces as they did what they had to do.

Someone complained that if you stood up you'd step outside the hull.  I thought that was awesome.  I'd sit out on the wing if they had the option just to check out the perspective.  I think it's great to get views that would not normally be had if you were there at the time.  I don't understand that beef at all.

Very immersive into the experience of the bombing raids into Berlin. Also the attack by a Messerschmitt 109 at night was eye opening. Didn't know they did that and found out recently that their was a team called the "Wild Boars" that flew 109's at night attacking bombers that were being illuminated by the search lights below.
If you have any interest in history, you should get this.  It lets you be in a plane while a bombing run was going on.

This is probably the best VR experience I've had to date.  The detail is incredible.  It felt like I was acutally in the plane on the bombing run.  Very well done.  This is the app that I use to introduce my friends and family to VR, and most have been absolutely speachless afterwards.  Thank you very much for sharing.  Makes me realize how heroic these guys were during WWII.

you can,t get more accurate experience than an actual recording of the real heros who actually did this for real anyone who does not rate this in my opinion is an idiot.
its free because its the reason we live like we do Today
its also a great vr experience Highly recommend

review_title: Beyond words how amazing this is....
one_reviews_text:
This is without a doubt the most chilling but real representation of a bombing raid in mid/late WW2.
Every single hair on my body is standing on end.
I almost cheered when they flew back over the coast!
It's chilling to hear the original audio while seeing the aviation crew working around you inside the plane.

This was absolutely insane.. Getting to experience such rich history like you are there is crazy. Getting to see these pilots brave the storm of flak is phenomonal. I REALLY hope there are more of these historic experiences to come.. It could teach so much!!!!!!

As a life-long student of history, I have never witnessed the stench and naked fear of actual war as experienced in this immersive heart-pounding fear-gripping display--you are there for every booming concusion of flak as you pray for your safe return through the bristling forest of shells from axis fighters while mates explode from all compass points in fireballs whirling to their deaths you realize you are one of the blessed ones only to know that in short time you must harness your flight suit and do it once more. Hail to these brave men and the creativity of those whose genius and dedicatiion would see their sacrifice would never  go unsung.

While the history, authentic recordings and setting is promising, the technical level fails to immerse. The plane is alright, the surroundings and effects are poor. There's issues with the camera position and no way of beefing up the graphic settings, AA etc. 
It's all completely static, one would expect an option to switch camera in each setpiece, but no. 
Wonder who are all those people that 5 star this, being free does not grant 5 stars automatically in my book.

The reenactment is awesome and the visuals stunning! Very moving and powerful. I wish it would have been longer or had other missions but there is nothing bad to say about this one.

Stay seated inside the Lancaster or step out on the wing for an unfettered view. Just WOW!

Please! Give us more great works like this!

Ok so im a bit of a history buff anyway.   But this really blew me away.    Very immersive feeling.   Educational.   More of a little film than a game.  But simply gave me goosebumps to think of the way the men on the plane felt that day.   Very cool stuff.

Fabulous emotional VR experience. Join and witness the re enactment of a 1943 actual bombing raid on Berlin by a historic and decoratedLancaster bombing crew. I very nearly give it 5 stars, only the external views could have been better portrayed. Excellent educational experience from the BBC. Well done

What  a  thought provoking experience .  
I  have  a 95 year old relative who was  an anti aircraft gunner in WWII and to see  and feel the situation she was  in  on the ground from the  Bombing aircraft along with the amazing  real life commentary has left me  reeling.  
 Maybe one day  the BBC could do a VR experience from the British ground defence batteries which would give a total view of the all out bombing raids of the war?
I will show this to my children before the visit her their great nana next week  and I dont think they will look at her in the same light again! 
All of the contrasting humanity within the Lancaster and the scenes outside the aircraft are testament to the  unfathomable courage of the crews who knew each raid was a 'toss of the coin' chance of survival.
Only the groundbreaking 'VR' can bring these hithertoo only imaginable experiences to life.
Thank you VR and BBC.

First review i write since ive owned a rift.I have waited for a flying simulation like this.I really felt like i were in the plane with them.It ran flawlessly on my pc.Please,Please,give me more of this.

A very authentic experience voiced by the actual crew of a Lancaster. I've read a 1 star review on here saying how the lack of engine exhaust gas and inaccurate dials made this a terrible experience, and I laughed. This is an excellent visual gift (free) to go along with the incredible audio recorded from the flight and I think it is superb. I believe this may soon become a teaching tool, and I don't think I've ever experienced something as profound as this in VR. When they sight the British coast and burst out into song, massive thanks and respect for the young men and women who carried out such terrifying jobs and did so with a smile.

Winners write history.

What some cannot imagine is that these attacks had about 95% collateral damage and we now have been first person witnesses of this heroic strategy. These attacks killed 600.000 children, women, old men while most soldiers were at the front, or already dead at this point of the war. Many more were badly injured and millions became homeless refugees. Imagine what "Bombed out" means - These attacks had even more civilian casualties than the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki together. Not only this, but dying was much more painful for the children in fire and below broken buildings compared to getting obliterated by an atomic bomb.

BBC I want you to show the other side too, maybe as second menu selection: Sirens. A woman without her husband (who was indoctrinated as patriot from childhood and then taken by the regime as cannon fodder), fleeing through burning streets. Trying to reach the nearest bunker. Just to die shortly before reaching it, buried by rocks, while seeing her children surrounded by flames that come closer and closer. Only my grandmother made it out of this night. The rest of the family was murdered by heroes.

Truly an awesome piece of Virtual Reality.  What these men had to go through is indescribable.  Feeling the cramped quarters, seeing the detail inside the plane, peaking around the pilot and co-pilot to see the instruments, hearing the hum of those Rolls Royce engines, the night sky lit up with flak, the voices over the radio, wow.  It makes me really excited for what is yet to come with VR.  Don't miss this one (you can experience this without touch too).  I just used the gamepad.

A wonderful and faithful recreation of a bomber raid on Berlin during WW2.  Audio commentary by a journalist during that time recreates the events as they happen.  A 'sit & watch' immersive experience where you can definitely feel the action as it happens.  A few times I found myself saying, 'sh*t!' when flak gets too close.  This is a free experience and it is a must have.  Wonderful piece of work!

review_title: Absolutely incredible - a must for rift
one_reviews_text:
I didn't expect much for a free app, but I've had some that have been great and I love experiences within the rift, and I'm also interested in experiencing scenarios like this first hand.

Although short (15 minutes or so) this experience truly transports you back in time, putting you at the helm with the crew. I won't spoil it by mentioning what happens, but needless to say I felt every goosebump along the way.

Stop reading the reviews, download the experience and appreciate our heroes.

I'm new to VR, but love my history. This is such a moving experience, it's incredible to be able to be inside a recreation of a bomber while listening to the actual audio of the flight. The immersion level is amazing, and it really does bring the audio to life.
What struck me was not just the bravery of the crew, but the bravery of the BBC sound engineers who were on the flight. 
Thanks BBC for putting this together

It was an interesting experience (with zero interaction) but when all is said and done really not much to it and felt rather empty.  While I understand it's based off of a real life event it all honestly seemed pretty uneventful aside from the brief fighter encounter.  What was there could be improved by adding more detail to the aircraft and crew behavior and allowing the user to jump to the different aircraft positions during each sequence would be a nice addition.  For me, the inherent quality of the recording further broke the immersion along with clipping through the aircraft.  However, I can't complain too much given the price and looking forward to more experience like this in the future.
It is aboslutely gorgeous , and i dont think that many vr stories can come this close to immerse you . Again its magnificent

considering this was done by the BBC, the overall quality was very poor, dont get me wrong, graphicaly, very good, standing next to lancaster on tarmac, wow, it looked so real, but in cockpit, things went downhill, apart fom crewmen, dials not working, level indicator on a permanant 10 o 15% bank, no hot exaust gasses from engines, barly any flak, only a few ground defensive guns firing, floodlights barly moving, being attacked by night fighter over boming area ?,  i could go on, but i think you get the impression, this could of been so much more, were you would of been very scared in the bomber.  I fly sims in vr, and you feel sence of flight, not in this though, the BBC should of dug depper and got it right, it should of been called an impression of what it was like, and not an experiance. After reading some other reviews, this isint gloryfing what bombers did its just trying to let you feel what it was like on a bombing run, but it could of been so much more realistic to get across what they were doing and feeling. poor job BBC.

Interesting application of VR - until they try to get real about the losses they caused: 'hundreds died'. Is this British understatement? Like saying 'a handful of people came into trouble because of a German-British Lose-Lose situation over two World Wars...' I admire and respect the reconstruction, but this VR instruction risks to replace the learning effect with propaganda - then its only a Horrordeck. Get real, guys. So many more died. Don't even think about doing this again...

This experience truly is why I think nothing beats beats VR in education. For a short while you feel like a part of the crew, flying in a cramped space and hoping not to get shot down by any enemy artillery. It placed a reality to war that I had never felt before, it's a steal that I got to experience this for free so I'll just be leaving this review instead.
One of the best games for detail and it shows you exactly what it would have been like they put so much work into this and it has turned out fantastic

review_title: Good for being free (who pays for this?)
one_reviews_text: Well made but the sound of flak is dissapointing. In reality the sound of flak was terrifying, here it sounds very generic and fake. I was suprised that the lives lost among the bomber crews were mentioned but the thousands of civilians who were killed were not. Pretty propaganda esque if you ask me.

Propaganda. You are still bombing civillians and part-taking in an unjustice operation over civillian targets. Black is not Black. White is not White. 

Bad models, clipping issue if you are standing, you are through the canopy of the bomber.
If you want to experience what those brave men went through,  download and play this experience.

VR is great for gaming but it really opens up powerful new ways to learn and experience things that simply weren’t possible. As someone listening just to a recording of a bombing raid I could see it being interesting enough, but to actually sit inside that cramped machine is truly something else and the greatest example of what VR can do. You really do feel lost in the moment and you can get a sense for just how it must have felt being cooped up in the dark in a small and barebones aircraft, being hunted down and rattled by the flak exploding around you. This gives a whole new appreciation of what it took to serve in the war and what kind of experience soldiers on all sides had to deal with. It’s also wonderful to see the comradeship of the crew and really feel it as you fly alongside them. 

As the actual quality of the app goes it’s mostly very good, with an odd little graphical glitch but not really anything you’d notice unless you went looking. Really superb job.

This is the stuff that brought on Brexit. While these men certainly went through had times, there is also the other side that they bombed. Millions died through bombing. Yet the BBC is on a continous boring decade long loop of repeating again and again the same patriotic stuff. Many of those bombed were not Nazis and could also not escape the actions of a run away right wing immigrant hating society. Two generations that weren't even involved in the war, keep on getting their brains washed with this one sided reporting. It was a massacre and the same mistakes are made now, with patriotic drivel driving nations against each other. Yet this mini segment of WW2 fails to mention anything unrelated to the deads of  the British alone. One can really only understand this point if one has seen the decade long programming put out by the BBC. It;s also funny hoew the American, French and Russians are never given the equivalent airtime to what their contribution to the War was.

review_title: This event caused me to be!
one_reviews_text:
In 1940s My grandma, a small child lived in Berlin, and when the raids picked up every night, her Mum knitted her a backpack and they carried the few things they could between them.
She told me stories of how they would hide under/behind anything they could - they most feared the fighters, who by this time had little enemy aircraft to shoot at, and would dive down shooting at anything that moved. Seeing my grandma today, a very old frail lady, it is difficult to imagine she was literally dodging bullets aged 7 - bullets my English grandad was busy loading into Spitfires for the RAF!
Having moved near a small town by Frankfurt - she was to meet my Grandad, some few years after wars end - they still live in that small town.
My grandads best friend - who also still lives opposite them - has a big flower nursery - and in their cellar are all the graffiti drawings and such they would scrawl on there when they were 7-14 years of age in those dark days.
The one thing i quickly picked up as a kid, with grandparents fighting for both sides - was that neither side won that war, and to quote Crimson Tide - "The true enemy of war, is war itself."
This bought a tear to my eye. A special and wonderful experience thanks to this wonderful tech. Can't wait to feel more history like this.
Please make a Dambuster version. :-)

This is the way i hope future brings documentaries, what would bring more emersive to the experience is camera shaking from shock waves, real 
instrumentation, and the animations was a bit poor, would allso have realtime light in the fractions on cockpit glas, the shotdown plane had a very weird aerodynamically angle on ground approach, like its the small stuff the makes it greate, but its still a good start! Now i hope they make one for the German side allso about the Junkers Ju-88 and Heinkel he-111 crews, Its not political people in the planes its Pilots whit crew fighting for their countrys, does not matter which side you are on...

Excellent.   Sure it would be possible to pick bits of it apart, but as an experience for everyone rather than especially for the rivet counters it really is superb, you might even say moving.  For those who question the German casualties quoted at the end I suggest you do some research and look up the details about the Berlin raid of the 3-4 Sept 1943, a total of 422 Germans were killed during the raid.  The raid, 316 bombers and 4 Mosquitoes, preceeded (not by much) the bomber campaign proper. Anyway, enough said on that, but watch it, it (VR) really paints a picture like no other medium can.

I like the original sounds, the aircraft and character modeling, but the ground and background modeling feels not so good compared to the rest. To me, it would have been even more immersive if there were some sort of structure on the ground, or stuff you can look at and not just a flat ground textured with huge spotlights and few explosions. Still worth the experience, you can feel the "at anytime could be your last thought" while flying over high risk areas.
ok so i  am not into history but THIS WAS GREAT so many details and it was just amazing siriously it was great keep up the great work

review_title: Awesome way to bring history to life
one_reviews_text: This is what VR excels at.  You'll feel real emotion as you fly in the bomber alongside the men who were really there.  Incredible experience!

Chilling and haunting vision of hell on earth using an actual WW2 audio recording. It's a valuable and valid record in itself, and in this day and age about as good as it gets. The audio is astonishing, the graphics excellent. You can almost smell the leather of the pilots' caps. The relief of the crew on the way back is palpable. A lot of the bombing fell short and hit civilian areas and this is acknowledged along with the high bomber casualty rate. It must have been terrifying.
Heroes, every single one of them.  Thank you BBC. This is amazing.

Sat here in the comfort of my home that these men and women secured by their heroic actions and I am crying.
What a scary event for these men. 
I'm so glad this experience was made. (And so glad I saw it virtually, rather than in real life) More people should experience this and other such documentaries.
Thank you for making this. I will be sharing this with visitors.

Very very good experience, don't think any other VR experience ever came this close to showing the madness of war and how extremely fortunate we are to live in peace.

When the plane entered the coast of Netherlands it really hit me - we are on the way to try to murder people we never met, while people on the ground are trying their hardest to try to murder us.

War - what is it good for - absolutely nothing :P

review_title: VR as a means to convey an experience
one_reviews_text: I am deeply moved by this experience. I am very interested in WOII material and have watched tons of documentaries and movies. This however is a whole other ballgame. Very immersive, beautifully done. Eventhough we only stand on the doorstep of what is possible with VR, this is already an engaging adventure, not just converying information but making you feel you where there. Respect for and thanks to everyone involved in making this experience. I also feel it is great that it is provided for free, would have been willing to pay, but i can understand this way the entry barrier is even lower.

Winston Churchil 20 August 1940

"We must never forget that all the time, night after night, month after month, our bomber squadrons travel far into Germany, find their targets in the darkness by the highest navigational skill, aim their attacks, often under the heaviest fire, often with serious loss, with deliberate, careful discrimination, and inflict shattering blows upon the whole of the technical and war-making structure of the Nazi power. On no part of the Royal Air Force does the weight of the war fall more heavily than on the daylight bombers who will play an invaluable part in the case of invasion and whose unflinching zeal it has been necessary in the meanwhile on numerous occasions to restrain… "

This is the best experience within VR I have had so far. To tie the authentic audio to an immersive visual experience together to relive a small piece of history is what VR excels at. Gaming in VR is good, but learning and getting to feel a part of history is truly inspiring. A part of your brain feels it's real, and the authentic audio really helps bring you into the scene. It highlights the courage and strength of will that the men and women who were brought into WW2, and honors them in the best way possible. Kudos to BBC and the company who brought this experience to VR.

You sit in a plane with several crewmen that bombs Berlin during WW2. Your position in the plane shifts several times, so you see different things. It's quite a display of light outside when they fly over Berlin in the night. Graphics are in some ways good, in some ways bad. This hardly ranks among the highest-quality productions. In some ways, it's quite an atmospheric experience. And coming along for a ride seems like a good way to experience historical events.

Vantage points are strange. You wind up sitting very close to the crewman, in some cases, maybe you even intersect them. VR makers should be respectful enough to avoid unexpected "intimacy" in VR. This is a crucial flaw that should be learned from.
It would be cool if it could be translated in other language.

The experience is not bad but I find it very sad that the focus is only on the crew of the bombers. At no point there is any moment to think about that you are going to bomb civilians. You will kill men, women, children, old and young, healthy and sick. You are not better than the Nazis bombing London.

Very good. VR is an amazing educational tool. Wow, to be in the bomber and hearing their voices was really interesting. The graphics, like the Apollo 11 experience, are not the best (compared to say Lone Echo), but they are good enough to give you a level of immersion. Thanks BBC for funding this and giving it out.

Worth a download and your time if you are at all interested in the subject matter. VR is powerful in that not only could it transport the user to a different place but also a different time. This experience is well done and kept my interests. Don't skip the radio broadcast portion.

Despite the incomplete detail (instruments, engine exhaust etc.) the "feel" of the experience is right on. I spent a career as a military navigator and spent a lot of time standing behid the copilot exactly as in the sim and this experience brought back vivid memories! Well done and lets see some more!

review_title: Great stuff from the makers of Apollo 11
one_reviews_text:
As soon as I saw this was available I immediately downloaded and dived in.   My initial thoughts were 'hmm this reminds me of Apollo 11 in style' - and sure enough it is the same people behind this.

That's a great thing because Immersive VR Education have produced some of the best VR content out there and I loved Apollo 11 and Titanic VR - and if you loved those , you will love this and amazingly it is free.

The graphics are excellent as always and coupled with the real radio broadcast it is as close as you are going to get to expriencing what our heros did in the second world war. 

This sort of thing is exactly what VR is all about - a captivating way of education people about major events in history.

ive seen (on video) and heard a LOT of ww2.  this is just like being in a lancaster bomber and something from the past comes alive.  thx for making this.   its is awesome.   now u commidet yourself to making this the trailer of your future accopenmablabkla....cant spell thet word but i think u got the idea.    go make something about ww2 in 3d.....from the lancasters to the kz deathscamps.   sas sbs heroic attacks.   u can do it......best wishes for this getting a trend.....ill support you anyday.

In the sea of N64-like graphics on some of the VR games, this short experience looks wonderful. I especially liked looking down during the last sequence. It actually seemed real looking out of that gritty window. Excellent for free content.

I have to be honest. I feel like i was in history. I think VR is good in some ways. To take us back to when things happen. Also how they was. Tho sometimes it can be bad to see some of the history. By tiggering. But i have to be honest. I think it good. For everyone to watch this. This will open your mind to a new lvl. Knowing what the men and woman have to go through. Fighting Each Day...

review_title: A Great Re-use of a Vintage Recording
one_reviews_text: As much as I frequently disagree with the BBC's output this is a great piece of work. The reporter clearly had a huge pair of stones as he controlled his fear incredibly well. It is a good piece of work for further reflection upon the terrible things that everyday Joe's had to do to defend their world. Obviously, views on the, often inaccurate, night-time bombing vary from person to person but let's not detract from the brave men that did this. It's true that civilians suffered tremendously as a result of this, but let's not judge too harshly from our pampered, insulated, and relatively easy lives.
I just went out and bought VR headset so I can try 1943 Berlin blitz. It says purchased but how do I download it?

To understand RAF Bomber Command in 1944 - 45, a time when Europe was in `Total War` you have to understand the plight of it's crews. 19, 20, 21 years of age. Volunteers the lot. Climbing into the night aboard their Lancasters, Stirlings and Halifaxes to do battle with an unseen foe. 8 hour trips enduring bitter cold, constant fear interspersed by flak, search lights and night fighters. When death came it came sudden as a flash. If you were lucky you might get out. If not a burning pyre on the ground, a marker to another seven aircrew lost.
War is a terrible thing but we must not forget the sacrifice of the brave men and women who give their lives in all wars for our freedom. None moreso than the thousands of crewmen from Bomber Command who's only epitaph was `Failed to return`.
Lest We Forget.

review_title: A great use of original recordings.
one_reviews_text: My grandfather was a surgeon in East Anglia during World War II, looking after injured airmen, so he knew very well the tragedy of war.  This VR experience does a great job of showing what the airmen went through during the unfortunate, but necessary raids on Germany to defeat the Nazis.
I watched this on Remembrance Day. To say I lived every moment is an understatement. A truly powerful piece of work and a testament to the bravery of the Bomber Command crews. Superb.

Really appreciate the fact that actual recording was used and not voice actors reenacting. Shame that we probably wont get a similar sort of thing from the Axis/German side of things. I appreciate history when you get points of view from both sides of the argument and not just the victors. 

As some others pointed out, the overall volume of visible flack was probably much higher than shown in this presenation, but hey, who really knows what it's like except the original flight crew.

This is what VR is all about - Breathtaking graphics and atmosphere trully makes you feel you are in the aircraft . The feeling and suspense is transmited to you despite the fact you are a viewer - The fact that there is an interaction of sorts with the crew and you through the narative is extraordinary and makes you find yourself looking at each crew member and waving at them only to have them respond . Unvelievable - Well done a million times . My grandfather was is the Berlin airlift as a navigator - This has brought me so much closer to what he might have experienced in his life. Thank you BBC and creaters so much !

I felt very emotional and sad watching this and it gives you a sense of how frightening it would have been to get the job done; much respect to war vets and my great grandad  who would have experienced similair events in world war 1.
Loved it nothing is more amazing then to see and hear what went on in that air craft. I hope they make more like this.

First off thanks for the freebie  :)   anyways So...you get to go along on a bombing mission, and you feel the clausterphobia in the cramped quarters of the plane and you jump around to different vantage points. I could have used some more shaking and tilting of the plane as its buffeted by wind and flak so I didnt feel like I was on a disney ride. yes I know some people get sick in VR...but I dont, so dont punish me with watered down physics.offfer a realism experience.  you also see with things like this how some developers show that sometimes "scenes..and experiences" are just as powerful as full games maybe even more so. I would like to see more little experiences like this...like maybe being on the deck of a ship as a tidal wave rears up in the distance and heads towards the ship....or maybe seeing Godzilla stomp around a city in the distance etc etc. anyways great job

An eye opener into the conditions, fighting spirit and bravery shown time and again by heroes of 'the greatest generation' A first class insight and rather clever use of VR mixed with a real wartime corespondents broadcast.. Bravo! a fitting tribute to the men of Bomber Command
An oppressive but instructive experience.

I thought this experience was absolutely amazing.  There you are inside a WWII era Lancaster Bomber, listening to an accompanying reporter recording his descriptions of the events unfolding live as the journey continues... this is a REAL recording from historical archives, and yet you can see him sat there in the airplane at the same time.  This may be a VR reproduction, but this is a snapshot of a real moment and every person aboard this plane were real human beings doing heroic work.  It felt like I was a ghost, gone back in history to look over the shoulders of these men as the event unfolded - amazing!  I was so transported into the experience I had to suppress almost-true panic as the flak shells began exploding and a nearby friendly was shot down.  I was so happy to return to friendly shores, and very moved to hear the co-pilot sing a tune.  I've read, studied, and thought often about the world wars over the years... this is one of the times I've felt most viscerally connected to the experience and my education and respect has increased in kind.  Bravo BBC - I would love for you to continue producing VR experiences like this!
Everyone should experience this. Gives you a glimpse into what these brave soldiers had to do. Wish there was more of these world war experiences . Thank you!

My late grandfather was a rear gunner on Lancasters during the latter half of WW2 and this allowed my sons and I to have a small insight as to what he and the rest of his crew would have experienced.  All in a very immersive experience.

Apart from a few shortcomings regarding instrument accuracy and a few gfx glitches... the original recording and the vr experience really create an immersive atmosphere in which to experience a harrowing part of WW2. Well done BBC... one (purposeful?) inaccuracy is the hundreds of civilians killed?... more like thousands...

Although the graphics are of a lower quality, the story is not.  The experience is an amazing one, it puts you in the BBC reporters shoes on that day.  As we began to take off the fact that all of the people in the plane were real set in.  it made the flight more real than i'd like it to be.  I strongly reccomend this download.
An incredibly powerful and terrifying experience. People may thing they have some idea of what the war was like through playing games, but THIS is something else. An absolute must experience!

The beginning and start of run in Belin is great but then sound crashes and I have to exit out of Oculus to get it back.  Made it through Berlin one time but then crashed as was turning back to England.  Run Oculus stuff full out on my system.  Can't find a tech support email or anything online.
Not a really a game but it's a nice thing to listen to and look around in. BTW what's up with all these "games, but not games" on the Oculus store and with VR "games" in general?

The immerssion was great in this documentary experience. There are a few hicups, for me it was mainly duo to where the viewpoint is placed. Sometimes to high and other times to low. That didn't matter much tho, sound and visuals are on point. Dont miss out on this one. Great job BBC! :)
Experiences like this one always make me cry and therefore help the glue for the padding to dissolve. Haha, I really need to buy a VR cover before the whole padding falls off
Beautifully emmersive.  I loved hearing the voices of these brave men.  Worth your time to experience and share with anyone who may be interested in history.

review_title: This is why I got VR.
one_reviews_text: I have nothing to add that hasn't already been said.  This was so meticulously detailed and chillingly real I was speechless.   The use of an actual recording was simply brilliant.  My 82 year old dad was simply awestruck.

The Idea was cool but all other is a Joke.
That feels not like a survival Battle in the Sky. That was War pure and that feeling comes remotely not over me. Too simple.

This is a really well put together experience. Visuals are great (not spectacular, but very good, even compared to some paid experiences), and the original narration takes you back to 1943. There's no interaction (you don't even see your hands), so just sit back and enjoy.

Superb.  If you haven't downloaded this, do so now.  It gives a small insight into the lives of a bomber crew on their way to/from an Op, it doesn't glorify their role but gives you a seat in their Lancaster on the way to Berlin.

A very, very nice implementation of a historical event, and it's free?? To hear it in the voices of the original flyers makes it even more gripping. Keep up the great work BBC - I'd love to see the American daylight bombing as a companion piece.

really cool idea and implementation....I wish there would be such kind of vr experience where you could join german sodiers in messerschmitt planes and junkers bombers flying over to london! thumbs up for this one!
I dont see the point for such a content. For me the experience wasnt entertaining at all, just boring.. nothing else.

Although an interesting recording by itself, VR has brought new life to this historical moment that even those of us who grew up nodding off during history lectures would find fascinating! Great graphics and good narrative content.

Well that was an experience. Even as a German.

You feel a little bit scared while the flak is basically shooting at you. Great Work of Art.
I'd give 3 stars if you had to pay for this but for a free application it is incredible! Thanks for the experience.
Really enjoyed this experience.  Amazing detail in the Lancaster bomber, and tying it all in with the original recording. Didn't want it to end. Well done BBC and VRimmersive team.

It amazes me just how calm these brave men were in such conditions; knowing that at any minute they could be shot out of the sky.

War is bad, I won't deny.  This is a really good VR experience that we should all watch to honour those who had to go through it.

review_title: Bringing new life to old recordings
one_reviews_text: Ok, the graphic quality may not be perfect and subtitles would help but the concept is brilliant.  Well done BBC and all involved. VR needs more of this type of content.
Excellent idea, brilliantly and thoughtfully executed - a great way to visualise what these brave aircrews did in WW2. Great VR experience and emotional storytelling in VR.
This is a great experience. Hope to see more WW 1/2 content like this to help comprehend what it was like.
Quality production, and something you need to experience rather than read other peoples descriptions of.  Check it out!
Wow.
Sad to see what these guys went through, it was scary enough in VR.
These kind of historical experiences help make VR essential.  Nowhere else can you get this deep of an immersion of past experiences.  Thanks and keep the history coming.
What can i say, this is incredible. You really feel apart of it and in some ways it makes you quite emotional.

Nice experience although there is one thing that could be added or fix:
- Need subtitles because it's too complicated to understand for non-natives.
Well done and it gave you a VERY small taste of what it must have been like to be there. We are but voyeurs and still it grips you. Free experience that must not be missed.
Remarkablly thought provoking experience, surreally calm yet terrifying...
This is such a moving experience that no one should skip out on this. Highly recommended and completely loved it.
amazing, immersive and glorious
Tears in my eyes in the end (almost)
Puts you right in the thick of the fight. Great effort BBC.
I am a curator of NASA/Moffett Field Museum (in the Cloud), @ Silicon Valley, Calif. This is it the future of education. Keep going BBC!
Excellent graphics and animation. Extreemly imersive and puts you right in the action making you feel like one of the crew.
This was a really great experience and definately delivers a lot on the promise of VR.
Very Immersive and loved the authentic radio broadcast! This is a must see!!

I felt sad of the things we have to do when mad crazy, greedy, evil men start wars. 

I enjoyed it and oh my GOD those men are brave AF.
Guys, for a free experience this is amazing. You really have no reason not to try this! Fun and educational.
You know it's the coolest airforce when they bring their own DJ on missions. :)
I would absolutely reccomend this experience
...for this immersive experience. For free!! You did a great job.
The only thing missing was the smell of fear, the cold, and the bacon and egg flavoured belches.
very, very boring
Wow, just wow. Combining original audio with VR is a brilliant idea and implemented amazingly
Very nicely done. Look forward to more history like this!!!
The real audio recording really puts you in the experience
Absolutlely Amazing.......
Great experience guys. Thanks for hard work put into this simulation. Felt very real.
just awsome, a must see, you wont be dissapointed
Great experience both visually and commentary wise. Highly recommended.
This is an awesome experience with actual audio. Loved it!!
Great perspective on a bombing mission

review_title: Makes me so proud to be British
one_reviews_text: What an amazing VR experience. Best yet.
Wow!!! No more to to say
Imagine the history channel (when it was good) on steroids
Really well done! Atmospherically and in terms of music!
Amazing for a free app.  Highly recommend !
Very good .
Amazing!
Keep it coming.
I really enjoyed this. It's basically  an immersive documentary. totally recommend it.

review_title: An incredible example of what VR can do.
one_reviews_text:
Fantastic demonstration of how VR has the ability to put us right into history in the most realistic and uncompromising way imagineable. 
Fantastic job of the models, textures but particularly the audio, felt like you were really there in the first 10 seconds. Could well be a paid experience with it's quality but very grateful that's not, else I may never have experienced it.

review_title: A powerful way to learn about history
one_reviews_text: Great job BBC!  I found it an immersive and fascinating look into the flight of a Lancaster bomber.  It made me think of all the pilots who went out and fought for their countries - many of whom did not return.  As a 40 something adult I cant really comprehend what they went through - but this begins to show it in ways regular film cannot.  I will show this to my kids.  I wish I couldve shared this with my Grandfather.  The audio from the time is amazing.  Graphically pretty simplistic in places - but I dont think that matters at all.  If only all history could be taught with experiences like this!

What a piece this is. Short, but oh so sweet. I've had many a VR experience, but truth be told, this one really did something special for me. Many people talk of VR experiences being so real they thought they were there. After playing so many titles, it is tough for me to get that experience anymore. I've rarely achieved the immersion this game gave to me. I think this came from the fact that the audio truly happened. This was the real broadcast from my understanding. What sent shivers down my spine was that these men truly lived this, and there was I, sat right next to them. Truly breathtaking. The bravery of these men was unparalled. Their voices don't shake, they hardly talk out of turn, and all with death just mere feet from them. You have to experience it to know what I'm saying. It's free. If nothing else, download it to know what these men went through. Well done BBC. My thanks.

Can't really complain considering it's a freebie, and if you're into WWII history, you can probably add another star to the rating. There are a couple of things that threw me out of the experience though.

First off was that after recentering at the start, some of the positions it puts you in feel slightly off. At the start taking off, your head feels slightly too far back, and it's easy to clip through the geometry if you turn around.

In the cockpit (and behind the bomber as well), it felt like you should have been maybe 6 inches to a foot higher just to get a better view.

In the section looking back at the rear gunner, my head (and I've run through it twice now) was definitely too far back and off center, and was clipping through the geometry for the dome.

At one point, the navigator moved his hand and his pencil floated in mid air for a couple of seconds before reattaching to his hand.

There is noticably no detail on the cockpit instruments.

If you have a Buttkicker or a Subpac (or equivalent), crank it up - it certianly adds to the immersion with this.

You really feel like you are in the raid, well done BBC.

The radio show is also very good. he says the raid was 38 years ago at that point so its a 1981 radio show. The detail in the room was nice, the needle arm slowly working its way across the record. Only let down by the clock not moving (maybe its broken ... lol)

All in all, one of the best none interactive experiences I've had in VR so far.
One of the best educational experiences I've seen so far. Well polished. Great educational value.
Brave men. So calm and collected in the midst of such adversity. And the song at the end, very touching.
good
This is what VR was made for. Experiences like this show us what those harrowing situations were really like, and give you a taste of what people went through in our name.

Outstanding work, the interior detail of the Lancaster is superb and on par with payware flight sims.  Immsersive, in that you can see the recorder spinning behind the radio operator, as you are there among the crew and listen to the actual intercom audio and narration that was made on it 75 years ago.   A must see...can you imagine reporters being allowed as crew on bombing missions today?

As a german (im not), must suck reliving the world bombing your house. And the the worst part, everybody being happy about it. Lets make sure noone ever will have to live similar experiences in the future. About the experience in specific, since im not english and i cant understand very good english it was impossible to understand what was being said, thus it was a very boring experience for me. Maybe there is a possibility for subs in the future?

review_title: Very impressive and realistic - loved it
one_reviews_text:
I am a very experienced Flight Sim pilot, and this is an amzing medium to share the real sounds, lights and cramped environment these brave airman lived and fought in.
Please make more.
